Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WNF-93F1-JB20-G00M-00000-00Amazon's Record Profit Streak Ends with Weak Earnings on Increased Costs; SpaceX StarHopper Prototype Takes Off and Lands Successfully; Google Posts Strong Second Quarter Earnings as Hazards Mount; 2Q GDP Due Cut At 8:30 E.T. This Morning; Economist Expect 1.8 Percent GDP Growth In 2Q; Rprts: China Believe FedEx Withheld Over 100 Packages Of Huawei Tech; Colorado Robocalls Reigned In; California Fuel Efficiency Deal; "Once Upon A Time In Hollywood" Debuts In Theaters2019-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:53ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTGary B. Smith, Jack Brewer, Ken MahoneyNEWSDomestic072601cb.231Amazon's Record Profit Streak Ends with Weak Earnings on Increased Costs; SpaceX StarHopper Prototype Takes Off and Lands Successfully; Google Posts Strong Second Quarter Earnings as Hazards Mount; 2Q GDP Due Cut At 8:30 E.T. This Morning; Economist Expect 1.8 Percent GDP Growth In 2Q; Rprts: China Believe FedEx Withheld Over 100 Packages Of Huawei Tech; Colorado Robocalls Reigned In; California Fuel Efficiency Deal; "Once Upon A Time In Hollywood" Debuts In TheatersMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Jon Hilsenrath, Michael Tammero

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you, and happy Friday, everybody, TGIF, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Friday, July 26th, your top stories right now, 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The pulse of the economy on tap today, second quarter GDP out later this morning, we are all over it, it is the final big read before the next week Fed meeting. We'll have the number and what it could mean for changes and at the Fed and chances of that big rate cut coming next week.

Focus on earnings, once again, Google's parent, Alphabet, beating expectations last night, posting strong growth, the stock rising this morning in the premarket, and then Amazon's string of record profits coming to an end, the stock is down this morning, 1-1/2 percent, Alphabet having a good morning, up better than 8 percent right now.

Still more tech on deck today, with Twitter, out later this morning, also reporting, fast food giant, McDonald's, we've got all of the numbers on the earning season that is better than lowered expectations.

Then, the 2020 race is on. Democrats are taking the lead, who is falling behind? We've got the latest polls ahead of the big Democratic debates coming up, end of the month. Then, SpaceX reaching for the stars, two big successes, launching a rocket to space station and getting the giant Starhopper, that even Elon Musk says, looks like a water tower, to blast off the ground.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

All right, we've got a big program this morning, joining the conversation, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Kadina Group president, Gary B. Smith is here, and the Brewer Group CEO, former investment banker and former NFL star, Jack Brewer, great to see everybody today.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Happy Friday.

MCDOWELL: Nobody says my name better than you, Maria Bartiromo.

BARTIROMO: Rally up, everybody, Dagen is in the house. Come on.

MCDOWELL: So sweet.

BARTIROMO: All right, we've got GDP this morning, that's going to be important.

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. We're going to dig into that. So, we're expecting almost two percent growth, 1.8 percent growth, so the things to watch out for, I'm just going to jump ahead. Household spending infrastructure, investment and military build-up could contribute four percentage points to the GDP, but we're going to get a reversal inventory draw downs and movements in the trade deficit.

That's what is, in part, gave us that 3.1 percent growth in the first quarter, so you're going to see a reversal of that. The key thing, and we both talked to Stephanie Pomboy, she said was, how rapidly the inventories are drawn down. She suspects if the rap -- the inventory draw down isn't as fast as a lot of people expect, you could press to the up side.

BARTIROMO: So, the focus on the inventory, the draw down, is this priced into the market, Gary. What do you think market is looking for today?

GARY B. SMITH, PRESIDENT, KADINA GROUP: Well, I think, definitely going to be focused on the Twitter earnings.

BARTIROMO: Twitter earnings. They're out at 7:00 a.m.

SMITH: I think we have a real focus right now, whether good or bad, whether it's lawsuits against the companies like Google, or whether it's at their monopolies, but the whole focus seems to be, you know, we saw with Amazon, we saw with Google, it's all really focused on big tech right now, so --

And, you know, Twitter is just -- is one part that. I think more of a minor part, but I think that's what we're going to be looking at.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we want to -- we want to look at that because there's also this whole conversation about potential regulation coming --

SMITH: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: So there's that.

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You met with President Trump.

JACK BREWER, CEO, BREWER GROUP: Yes, I did.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I want to hear about the meeting.

BREWER: Yes. It was a -- it was a great meeting. You know, race relations right now are the topic of conversation across this country and, you know, I just felt like it's time to bring some unity to the conversation and really be real, look at statistics and policy.

You know, unfortunately, people have so much emotion tied in this, but they're ignoring policy, and so our meeting was about, you know, the real things that are affecting the black community.

BARTIROMO: And I want you to go through it this morning because you did such a great job in terms of explaining the issues facing cities like Chicago, others as well, so we'll get into that.

Also joining the conversation this morning, the founder of Livongo Health, the executive chairman, Glen Tullman is here. Former White House press secretary and America First Action senior advisor, Sean Spicer, joining us this morning, along with former senior adviser to George W. Bush, FOX News contributor, Karl Rove.

Former Wall Street Journal editorial board member and Trumponomics co- author, Stephen Moore, joining us, as well, lot to say about the Fed with Stephen Moore this morning, ahead of the Fed meeting next week.

Amazon had an earnings missed, the technology giant reporting lower than expected results per share, that was pressured by increased shipping costs. Google, on the other hand, posted strong second quarter numbers, despite the potential for future regulation.

Let's talk tech for a second, your thoughts, you said Google is one that you're watching in addition to Twitter. Right, Gary?

SMITH: Yes, exactly. But the real, I think, non-event, honesty, is the Amazon loss. This is a company you want to invest in the future. You know, Amazon is building and continues to build a mote and that mote is their way to get products to the customer, they first started as two-day, now we're down to one-day. No one else can replicate that, maybe Wal-mart is trying.

The problem with the Googles of the world is they're more intellectual companies. You can do search elsewhere. You can do e-mail elsewhere. You can't get your products the next day which were all now becoming addicted to --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SMITH: -- from anyone else.

BARTIROMO: It's completely changed the industry. Yesterday, we have on the set the CEO and chairman of UPS.

SMITH: Right.

BARTIROMO: And you know, it's just become an expectation that I want that package tomorrow.

SMITH: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And Amazon just has basically changed everybody. So now, they've got seven-day shipping, they've got, you know, UPS is doing it, obviously, FedEx.

SMITH: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: But Amazon changed the game on this.

SMITH: And here's the thing, you can do -- anyone, almost anyone can do cloud computing, almost anyone can do some of the things, not with the level of execution that Google can, you can't replicate unless you build the infrastructure by the retail centers, have the highways to deliver goods the next day. That's the barrier to entry that Amazon continues to create.

MCDOWELL: Amazon stock was up 30 percent year-to-date before this earnings report. It's down slightly in premarket trading, but the good news in this report is the revenue numbers, so revenue, after shrinking over the past four quarters, four periods, revenue was up 20 percent.

SMITH: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: So that's what -- that's exactly what investors were looking for.

BARTIROMO: And hasn't that been the trend for Amazon, from the get-go, when it went public? It was never really focused on earnings, but more on revenue growth.

MCDOWELL: But then the investors got really excited about the streak of record profits that it was reporting, so that was over, but not the revenue growth.

SMITH: We think about -- we always reference -- you know, China has this 25-year plan. It's Amazon that is vesting -- is investing 25 years into the future.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

SMITH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Listen, what about Facebook? Breaking up Facebook, the co-founder -- one of the co-founders is Chris Hughes, remember a couple of weeks back, a month maybe, he wrote piece -- big piece about breaking up Facebook, and everybody was thinking, wow, this is one of the co-founders and he's behind the breakup.

He's reportedly working with the Department of Justice now on an antitrust case against Facebook. This, as 2020 presidential candidate Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard is suing Google now, for $50 million over free speech, after it suspended her ad accounts following the first Democratic primary debate.

This is the second lawsuit we're seeing against this group. Devin Nunes is suing Twitter, which I talked about a lot. Now, Tulsi Gabbard is suing Google. What do you -- what do you think about this, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: I think it's a huge deal that you have a Democratic candidate for president going after one of the big tech companies. Again, she's seeking $50 million in damages, but it shines a lot -- this is, again, the dislike of the abuse of people's privacy, and the heft of these companies.

It is a bipartisan issue that the left and the right are both, well, the left, and say, President Trump and some people in the Republican Party are united on this. This is -- when you have people far-right and far-left coming together on an issue, this is not good news for the technology.

BARTIROMO: Elizabeth Warren and Ted Cruz, both agreeing on it that they want to break up these companies.

SMITH: I slightly disagree. I think this is a publicity stunt. I think now it's the hot thing to pick on tech companies, and I think it's not a $50 million-dollar lawsuit, it's a $50 million-dollar advertising campaign for the rest of her political career. It seems cool to sue Google --

BARTIROMO: I don't think so. They really are censoring Conservative voices, I mean, we've seen evidence of it. And they've messed around with President Trump as well.

SMITH: I -- see, that's not my take. I think that -- I think Google, like any other companies, is not going to want to turn down dollars. I think that is their perception. But, you know, maybe that's my perception --

BARTIROMO: They also have their own ideology where things go and a lot of people wonder if we're going to see them cheat going into the 2020 election.

SMITH: No doubt about it, but so does the Wall Street Journal, so does New York Times, they all have their own ideology.

BARTIROMO: But they don't have the reach of a Facebook and they don't have the users that some of these big technology companies have. These companies are more powerful than they ever have been and they have a lot of influence in terms of dictating what people think.

SMITH: Do you think they should be regulated?

BARTIROMO: I would like to see more competition, in the market, that's how I see it, but I also don't want to see the wild west where you've got these major media companies having so much power and able to shut down certain conversations, yes.

SMITH: I'll flip -- I'll flip it the other way, Facebook, you know, we talk about regulating Facebook, I don't really care. Because, I think 99.9 percent of the people out there could live without Facebook. You could live without Google. You could -- so --

MCDOWELL: You can't live -- you can't use the internet without encountering Google, and they're abusing people's personal information in terms of selling advertising. People don't know --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- the insidious behavior because it's all behind a wall and any time they --

SMITH: You could use the internet without Google.

MCDOWELL: No, you can't, not really. Every 90 -- what two-thirds of all of the ads on the internet are served by Facebook or Google.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And they've got 90 percent market share.

MCDOWELL: You can't avoid -- you can't avoid interacting with these giant tech companies. And the American people and people around the world don't know how they're interacting with these people. They don't really know how Google and Facebook are using our personal data.

This is not signing up for a Facebook account, OK? I'm surfing the internet, even if I don't use Google search engine, you still -- Google still has sway over how ads are served, how data is collected, and I don't think that anybody in the government understands what goes on.

BARTIROMO: And how -- and how the search results come up. During the 2016 election, if you Google Donald Trump, you got massive hate articles. If you Google Hillary Clinton, it was like she's the greatest thing since sliced bread. That really happened.

So, they put their search results up in a certain way. That's not right. And I don't want to see it as an American citizen who wants to see fairness. I don't want to see the -- them have this power to sensor such conversation. It's not right. And, you know, viewers are reacting and that's why we're seeing people take notice and these lawsuits coming up.

Look, you've got the 2020 presidential race FOX News polls this morning, new FOX News polls, former vice president Joe Biden still in the lead with the -- among Democratic voters. Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, taking second and third place, take a look at that.

Then you've got a separate FOX News poll earlier this week that showed American's take on President Trump's performance on race regulations. It is the issue where it gets the lowest approval rating, as you can see now, 32 percent approving.

Jack Brewer was with President Trump. You have a different take on this, and tell us first. Explain the situation, what led you to go to get this meeting with the president?

BREWER: You know, any time you've got a chance to meet with the President, I mean, anyone would take it, but for me, it's deeper than that. You know, I spend a lot of my time in the urban areas, in the city communities. I've dedicated a big chunk of my life to helping, you know, African-Americans and people of color, not just here, but all across the world.

And to see so much political divide, right now, in our country, where rhetoric is coming from both sides, but people aren't talking about the facts and I've got a problem with that. You know, I have a problem. You know, as a person who voted for Barack Obama, twice, a lifelong Democrat, you know.

But now, I go into these same cities like Baltimore, I was just there three weeks ago. I just -- I just left from East Cleveland. I've been to a lot of the hardest hit areas where African-Americans are killing each other.

We have no -- we have no fathers in our house, 77 percent of African- American men are -- I'm sorry, 77 percent of African-American babies are born without a father. Those are deep, deep issues that we have to get to.

And so when I see a president like President Trump, who just released 3,100 inmates, 91 percent who are black, I mean, at some point, we've got to give credit where credit is due, and really, you know, put -- take actions and not just words.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And some of the things that he has done, the prison reform is something that you're very happy with.

BREWER: Yes, you have prison -- yes, you go down the list, Maria. You have prison reform, right? The first he overturned Bill Clinton's 1994 crime bill. That was massive incarceration for black men. If that -- if that is a racist president doing it, I don't know what to say.

MCDOWELL: Did you push him on the rhetoric, though, because you had a problem with what he said about professional football players.

BREWER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: A lot of people had a problem, will say go back to where you came from comment.

BREWER: Dagen, my comments to the president were, make it about his policies. Sometimes, he says things that people can make and to seeing what it is. But how are you going to call somebody racist, when they're led not more black men than any president in the history of the country?

How do you going to call somebody racist when they put billions of dollars, billions and billions of dollars back into the urban areas through opportunity zones? Come on, people. Wake up.

BARTIROMO: Two hundred and eighty-one people have been killed in Chicago, so far, this year.

BREWER: Yes, more than -- I mean, how many shots, Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

BREWER: There's a thousand shot.

BARTIROMO: More than that. All right, we'll take a break, when we come back, big day for earnings, Twitter and McDonald's on deck, right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. U.S. officials confirm Iran has test fired a ballistic missile, Lauren Simonetti with details and headlines this morning, Lauren, good morning to you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Tehran is defying Trump administration's warnings with a launch of a medium-range missile. The weapon launched earlier this week from the Southern Coast of Iran. It flew more than 600 miles before landing east of Tehran.

Now, tensions between Iran and the west, intensifying, after Iran seized a British-flagged tanker in the Strait of Hormuz last week.

Japan's SoftBank has unveiled a second technology, megafund. This one is even bigger than its $100 billion-dollar vision fund that calls the new fund, Vision Fund Two and it has commitments of 108 billion in capital from more than a dozen investors, including Apple and Microsoft, SoftBank itself, adding $38 billion.

And this SpaceX, celebrating another successful supply trip to the International Space Station. The Dragon spacecraft launched yesterday. It's now in orbit. It is scheduled to dock tomorrow. SpaceX also recovered the Falcon 9 first stage rocket which can be reused to save money.

The company also launching its next generation spacecraft StarHopper, the prototype hopped in the air for about 20 seconds before landing back on the ground. SpaceX is aiming to build a completely reusable spacecraft to send cargo and people into outer space, Maria, pretty cool stuff, but sometimes you've got to try this more than once.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true, good point, very cool. Thank you, Lauren. All right, quick break, and then coming up, New York police officers under attack, more videos coming out that show officers getting doused with water. Now, President Trump is slamming New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, for not doing anything about it.

Then, technology earnings are in focus, Google's parent, Alphabet, beat expectations last night, posting strong growth. The stock is up 8-1/2 percent. Amazon's string of record profits came to an end last night, the stock is down 1-1/2 percent, all that, on the other side of this break.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. So, Google, the stock to watch this morning, posting strong second quarter earnings last night, as it gears up for a regulatory fight in Washington. At the same time, Amazon's record quarterly profit streak -- came to a halt last night, mostly due to high shipping costs. We are also awaiting Twitter earnings in the next hour.

Joining us right now is Mahoney Asset Management CEO, Ken Mahoney, and Ken, it's great to see you, thanks so much for being here. You own tech?

KEN MAHONEY, CEO, MAHONEY ASSET MANAGEMENT: Yes, of course. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So, tell us what you thought about all of these numbers last night.

MAHONEY: Yes, I thought they're really good. We actually have a normal market now where we reward, like, good numbers, so where you beat and raise guidance and next, you get rewarded for it. And then we saw Amazon off a little bit on the net, again, put our money back in infrastructure that's down a little bit.

But yes, Google, as you mentioned, is up this morning, Starbucks is up this morning, Intel, the semis have been pretty high. Actually, we're not really much into semi space, but they're pretty high lately.

BARTIROMO: Has anything changed for Amazon, given the fact that the record streak was interrupted last night?

MAHONEY: I don't think so. They're putting so much money back into it. Everything's a race in getting to your doorstep, it was two days. As consumers, we're fine with that, now, it's one day. I think, pretty soon, could be knocking at your door, you know, within the hour, OK?

I want to take a canoe out and something is coming with. But to, really -- for the race to get to that point -- there's a lot of money putting into the infrastructure make that happen.

SMITH: Ken, let -- I want to -- have you -- you've looked into what, you know, Google's earnings, stuff like that. Isn't there story, though, primarily keeps coming back to, they're an advertising company?

MAHONEY: Ad sales, yes -- ad sales, yes.

SMITH: Is that -- can you keep doing that in the in the -- is that a sustainable business that has, as I've mentioned earlier, barriers to entry, but can a lot of people do that?

BARTIROMO: And is it like 90 percent of the -- of the revenue or profits is in ads?

MAHONEY: Eighty-two percent of search is on Google, so we're searching it.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MAHONEY: The algorithms get you there.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MAHONEY: And next thing, you're hitting that, and you go --

SMITH: But, I guess my point is this, you know, before Google, there were other search engines.

MAHONEY: Yes.

SMITH: Why can't there be a search engine at the next Google? And all of a sudden, what is -- what is Google going to do?

MAHONEY: Like you said, there were such barriers to entries, I mean, these guys like Amazon, all the ones you're mentioning this morning, have huge barriers to entry, why is there no (INAUDIBLE) Facebook social network, why isn't there another --

MCDOWELL: It's not just about search. It's about ads being served on the internet.

SMITH: No, no, no, we get that. But, it's via Google, though.

MAHONEY: Right.

MCDOWELL: Well, it's via Safari. Google has a relationship every Apple phone when you go on the Safari browser, it's via -- the searches are done via Google in the -- in the actual address bar. And they -- even when you're in privacy mode, that there's data being collected about you.

Like, literally, you -- they are tracking your every move via even when your location services are off, if you're logged into Google, then can track you.

BARTIROMO: I hate that.

MCDOWELL: They have tracked down murderers and the location of bodies just reporters based on Google. So, again, what does Google know about us, Google doesn't tell us, that's the point.

BARTIROMO: And then they decide to make the decision to not work with the Pentagon because they don't like -- they don't like the way the immigration policies going, and yet, they want to work with China, and inadvertently is working for China's military.

MAHONEY: That's crazy. You know what's so funny how Google --

BARTIROMO: That's ridiculous.

MAHONEY: I mean, back in the search days, I remember X site, they're not around anymore, Lycos, remember these names?

SMITH: Yes.

MAHONEY: You type something in, it was such a messy clutter search engine. Google was clean. Basically, it was a clean bar, and still to this day. A clean bar, you type what you're looking for and then it gives you the ad. But it's really interesting that Google won that space because of the simplicity of doing the searches.

BREWER: We're talking search, but think about Google. I use Google for my e-mail, I use Google for my dock stuff, I use Google --

MAHONEY: Google maps, probably.

BREWER: Maps.

(CROSSTALK)

BREWER: Everything.

BARTIROMO: How about ways?

MAHONEY: -- studio without Google maps.

BREWER: So, it takes over everything.

BARTIROMO: YouTube?

(CROSSTALK)

BREWER: Clicking on my phone, I'm on Google.

BARTIROMO: Is there any reason to think that the stock trades down because of a bigger regulatory bite?

MAHONEY: That's hard to say. I mean, look, they just escalated the words and everything this week. We'll see where that goes. But, you know, there's going to be a certain bit underneath it because they are earnings machine. Everything we're talking about here at the desk, they are an earnings machine, and that's something that, I think, at least puts some to the floor for the stock.

BARTIROMO: What a stock. Remember back in the day when it went public was at 75, it went public at $75.00 didn't it?

MAHONEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: In an unconventional way. And it never -- there wasn't a split or anything.

MAHONEY: No.

BARTIROMO: It's $1,200.

MCDOWELL: Yes, that was when their motto was, don't be evil.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So, again, they got rid of that for a reason.

MAHONEY: And then a Twitter coming up in a little bit.

BARTIROMO: Eighty-five? It was 85.

MAHONEY: Eighty-five, OK, thanks. So, we have Twitter coming up at 7:00 a.m. in a little while, expecting 0.18 cents. But, you know, there's not a lot of love for Twitter, Twitter is up 35 percent this year. And yet, you have the thing -- the last time, look, 11 buys analyst, 24 hold for analyst.

BARTIROMO: Twenty-four holds.

MAHONEY: Yes. So again, of course, if they beat that 0.18 cents, those holds will move over, of course, and investment banking, they'll move over to buys. But still, there's not a lot of love here for Twitter because they feel like there's not enough monetization.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MAHONEY: And you have millions of followers, Maria. It's like, how do they monetize, like --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MAHONEY: -- all of this, and they're still kind of -- I still -- they still haven't really figured that out.

BARTIROMO: Well, we'll see what happens when the company reports in about 30 minutes. We got those numbers coming up.

MAHONEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It's because your behavior on Twitter doesn't really reflect what you like and don't like and what you might buy and not buy. So, if you follow, say, Bernie Sanders, on Twitter, and follow all these progresses, does that really say anything about what kind of laundry detergent you like, really?

MAHONEY: But we won't go there.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. That's true. That's how they monetize, knowing what you like.

MCDOWELL: Right.

MAHONEY: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: We'll take a quick break, Ken, great to see you.

MAHONEY: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much, Ken Mahoney joining us. Coming up, Huawei versus FedEx, the Chinese technology company says that the delivery service lost more than 100 packages containing equipment of Huawei.

And then special delivery, one woman sweet Amazon surprise, arriving right on time for her birthday, all of that right after this. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Friday, July 26th. Your top stories right now, 6:31 a.m. on the East Coast.

We are on countdown mode to the GDP this morning. We are getting the first read of the second quarter. Later this morning, we will see what the growth looks like for the second quarter. 1.8 percent is the estimate. 1.8 percent growth, markets are up going into it. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 86 points on the Dow. S&P Futures up 10- 1/4, and the Nasdaq Futures up 40 points right now.

It is another big morning for earnings, of course. We're waiting on Twitter and McDonald's, they will be out momentarily. This after stocks fell yesterday. ECB president, Mario Draghi. (INAUDIBLE) yesterday, he was talking about more stimulus on the way but no rate cut or stimulus yesterday.

Global markets -- well, take a look at yesterday's close where the Dow was down to the triple digits. But European markets this morning are higher across the board. Bouncing this morning after the Mario Draghi comments yesterday, and the impact on U.S. markets. FTSE is up 43 points. CAC Quarante in Paris is up 27, and the DAX Index in Germany is up 48.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed as you see, mostly lower. Kyodo News reporting that Japan will remove South Korea from its list of most favored trading partners, effective August 2nd. The KOSPI Index down almost half a percent. Japan was down half a percent as well.

Meanwhile, rising U.S.-China tensions. FedEx reportedly suspected of illegally holding back over 100 Huawei packages. What it means out of the trade talks next week. We will take a look at that as Shanghai is the place that we will see a meeting for U.S.-China relations.

New York Police are under attack. President Donald Trump slamming presidential hopeful and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio last night after officers are hit with buckets of water.

This isn't several times this has happened now, and we have not seen any commentary from Bill de Blasio.

Apple buying Intel's wireless modem business. Intel on the rise pre- market. Take a look, it is up almost five percent. What the billion- dollar acquisition could mean for the future of iPhones.

Then, a very special delivery. One woman sweet Amazon surprise, arriving right on time for her birthday. She loves Amazon. That's actually a cake.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. But first, our top story this half an hour is the GDP. The second-quarter report you add at 8:30 a.m. Eastern this morning. It is expected to reveal. Slowing growth from the first quarter with the estimate showing growth of 1.8 percent. This after the first quarter GDP came in at 3.1 percent.

Joining us right now is Global Economics editor with The Wall Street Journal. Jon Hilsenrath. Jon, good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning, Maria. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: And we know there's lots of uncertainty over the trade situation that maybe is one issue that companies have sat on cash.

HILRENRATH: Right.

BARTIROMO: More so than we saw a year or so ago. What do you expecting from the GDP?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, a lot of us were talking about getting a slowdown in the first quarter of this year, and it didn't happen. We had pretty strong growth. It looks like that slowdown happened in the second quarter.

You know, consumers are doing pretty well right now with unemployment very low, and the stock market high. I think consumer spending is going to come in pretty well. The big question in this report is what's happening with business investment?

Is -- you know, are we seeing -- you know, what the economy needs and what a lot of people expected is a big burst of business investment spending with the tax cuts, and what we seeing follow-through on that.

The one other point I would make is look closely for revisions. They're going to be revisions to the data and not just for the first quarter, but going back into last year. And I'll be really interested to see if those revisions show any changes in that contours of this expansion.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Dagen, the Atlanta Fed is -- what it is the Atlanta Fed at now? 1.6 percent, I think for the -- for the Atlanta Fed, go ahead, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Right. Jon, I pointed out earlier if the inventory drawdown as to -- I don't want to steal somebody's line, but what the economy giveth, the economy taketh away and that's from Stephanie Pomboy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HILSENRATH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That it was inventory billed in the first quarter that helped boost the GDP to 3.1 percent. So, you will see a reversal of that. Is there any expectation of how fast that reversal will be? Because again, if it's not as rapid, you could have a surprise to the upside here.

HILSENRATH: Yes, that's true. The thing about inventories is -- you know, it's something that's very volatile. Companies add to inventories, sometimes if the economy isn't doing as well as they expect, and sometimes they do it in anticipation of future growth.

You know, what's happening with inventories doesn't really tell you what's going on with underlying growth. That's why economists tend to kind of dismiss the big swings that we get to the upside and the downside. And it looks like we're getting a little bit of that on both sides in the first quarter and second quarter.

I think, one of the ways to kind of look through that is to average out the growth numbers for the first quarter and second quarter because that will take out some of that inventory volatility.

GARY SMITH, PRESIDENT, KADINA GROUP: Hey, Jon. In the upcoming report, are there any specific numbers or facts in there that you look for as tells, or kind of canaries in the coal mine as to what might be coming up? Any indicators you say, oh, oh, that's troublesome for the future or that's great for the future.

HILSENRATH: Yes, absolutely. Business investment. So, you know, that this economy's growth is based on the productivity of workers. And the productivity of workers is going to improve when companies invest in more equipment, better equipment.

So, we got a good increase in business investment last year, and then it looked like it was starting to slow down and we're also seeing shifts in the kind of investment companies are doing.

You know, there's been a lot of investment in software over the last, over the last few quarters and some slowdown in big machinery. So, like I'm going to be looking at those investment numbers very carefully. And the troubling thing is we have seen some slowdown, and you're really at this point in the cycle want to see a follow through on this -- on those tax cuts to really assure us that we're getting productivity gains that will keep this economy going.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I'm really glad you mentioned software because that's something that people forget when you look at CapEx. Because in the first quarter, according to Cornerstone Macro, total real CapEx was up 4.8 percent, but software was up 11.2 percent.

HILSENRATH: Right. Right.

BARTIROMO: So, software is sort of like a must spend for companies. And so, we need to really see that when we're looking at overall CapEx. Otherwise, the CapEx number that we talked about is underestimating what actual CapEx is if you're not looking at software.

But Jon, I got to ask you about software and hardware from Huawei. Because Huawei versus FedEx is the story of the morning this morning.

HILSENRATH: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Chinese authorities say that they're investigating FedEx. They believe FedEx withheld more than 100 packages containing Huawei technology. That's according to Reuters this morning, based on the Chinese state media.

What do you think this means for the next round of trade talks next week? Gordon Chang out with a pretty good op-ed this morning in the journal, basically saying that, now, China is seeing Donald Trump differently, and is behaving differently. What's your take on the next round of trade talks here?

HILSENRATH: Well, on the Huawei issue, this is something that's been going -- been going on for a few months now. You know, originally Huawei asserted that FedEx diverted a couple of packages that were going from Japan to China, diverted them to the U.S. And there was this investigation -- it looks like this investigation, the Chinese are now saying, you know, uncovered that it was a lot more than a few packages.

So, I would call -- you know, what's coming out of China today and ask an escalation of these accusations that FedEx is in the middle of the whole U.S.-China Huawei fight. It certainly doesn't help the next round of trade negotiations.

You know, the president, when he met with President Xi in -- at the G20 meetings a few weeks ago, said that they were going to ease up on some of their sanctions on Huawei, and that continues to be a thorn in the side for both sides.

You know, frankly, we're just not seeing a lot of progress on these negotiations. It looks to me like it's something that could drag on for months if not years.

BARTIROMO: Yes, on a Gordon Chang's point in the op-ed this morning is basically saying, look, for a while, I thought that it was -- and a lot of people thought that it was the U.S. trying to maintain its dominant position in the world. But, in fact, it's not protecting its own status, it's protecting the system that the U.S. has a duty to stop China from becoming the largest military superpower because it's a communist nation. You don't want a communist nation being the dominant superpower.

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, that -- I mean, that's part of the whole backdrop of these negotiations -- is -- you know, that U.S. sees China as a growing threat not just economically, but also militarily, and geopolitically.

You know, they're also using their economic might to assert themselves through this project called the Belt and Road project where, you know, they're building, you know, political and economic ties across Asia and, you know, across Central Asia, and into Europe.

And you know, I think the U.S. is trying to counteract their assertion of becoming a major power. No question.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see what comes out of these talks next week. Jon, it's great to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

HILSENRATH: Sure, thank.

BARTIROMO: Jon Hilsenrath. Meanwhile, President Trump, clashing with New York City mayor, and 2020 hopeful Bill de Blasio over attacks on New York police officers. Lauren Simonetti with details and headlines now, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Maria, President Trump slamming de Blasio. Calling the drenching of NYPD officers unacceptable.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES (via telephone): Probably, the worst mayor in the history of New York City is done a bad job and now he's running for president. That people can't even believe it. He's a horrible mayor. The policeman just -- and women cannot stand him.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: De Blasio firing back, tweeting, "Crime's gone down, year after year in New York City, and it's not just because you finally left town." Three people have been arrested on misdemeanor charges and released.

Apple buying Intel smartphone modem business, the cost about a billion dollars. The acquisition means that Apple is on way to producing its own 5G modems for its smartphones, rather than having to rely on Qualcomm for the hardware.

Apple and Intel shares higher ahead of the opening bell. Intel surging after last night. It raised its full-year revenue guidance. Stock up almost five percent.

And a woman gets a pretty sweet delivery for her birthday. This Amazon box is actually a cake. Emily McGuire's husband thought it would be perfect since she gets about three Amazon packages every week, even the shipping label there is edible. And look, 1234 Birthday Lane, Happy Birthday, 2U is the address. Very cute.

Only three Amazon packages a week? That's not --

BARTIROMO: I like that cake.

SIMONETTI: But happy birthday, Emily.

BARTIROMO: Yes, happy birthday. Quick break, and then, robocall crackdown. A new house bill helps to curb the annoyance which state end most amount of calls, coming up next.

And then, returning to form. Director Quentin Tarantino is back with this ninth film. It's called, Once Upon a Time in Hollywood. Your weekend movie roundup, right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back headlines across America this morning. The Denver Post is reporting this: only one state generated more complaints about robocalls in Colorado where residents received 2.4 million calls a day. Just this week, the house approved the Stopping Bad Robocalls Act, a bill co-sponsored by Congresswoman Diana Degette, a Denver Democrat. A new study shows Coloradans lodged more robo complaints than people living in any other state except one, Nevada. Data shows robocall complaints to the FTC grew by 165 percent between 2014 and 2017, ringing in mostly during the summer peaking in August.

The L.A. Times this morning writes California reaches climate deal with automakers spurning Trump. Four major automakers agreeing to gradually increase fuel efficiency standards, rejecting the Trump administration's efforts to relax, tailpipe pollution roles. The deal between California Air Resources Board and Ford, Honda, Volkswagen and BMW cover about 30 percent of new cars and SUV sold in U.S.

And the Journal Sentinel says this morning, the Milwaukee County Zoo announce the birth of another adorable red panda -- it is a girl. Bundle of cuteness was born June 7th; tipping the scales at about 5.6 ounces. The cub and her mom are relaxing this summer, staying out of sight until September.

MCDOWELL: That's awesome. That deal with California is important whether the Trump administration because there's a two-tiered system in the country because of the Trump administration's position on the fuel economy standard. And so, President Obama was allowing California to drive essentially that decisioning-making about fuel efficiency standards. And now, there's this two-tiered system and we're -- the entire auto industry is watching to see if they can come together to create a national standard rather than one for California and one for the rest of the United States.

BARTIROMO: I guess that's what Trump administration was trying to do but California said: no, we're going to be on our own way.

MCDOWELL: And these automakers: Ford, Honda, BMW, and Volkswagen gave in.

BARTIROMO: All right. There you go. Coming up, returning to forum. Director Quinton Tarantino is back with his ninth film: "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood." Why it may be his last? That's next. Stay with us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So, Rick explain to the audience exactly what it is that a stunt devil does. Actors are required to do a lot of dangerous stuff. Cliff here is meant to help carry the load.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Is that how you describe your job, Cliff?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What carry his load?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, that's about right.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was a clip from "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood," Quinton Tarantino's new film debuts in theaters today. Joining us right now: "IN THE FOXLIGHT" Host, Michael Tammero. Michael great to see you.

MICHAEL TAMMERO, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST AND VICE PRESIDENT FOR MARKETING: Hello, my Maria.

BARTIROMO: So, I want to hear all about this film. Tarantino actually talked about retiring after this film.

TAMMERO: He did. Look, this film is rarity in Hollywood these days. It's a movie not -- with non-existing characters and non-franchise. No comment -- it's not based on comic book, and it's targeted towards adults. Who knew that we actually count in Hollywood these days, Maria? I'm not a big Tarantino fan, but I cannot wait to go see this movie. It's set in 1969. Hollywood in transition with whole Manson family and (INAUDIBLE) going on in the background in the murder of Sharon Tate.

The reviews have been fantastic. It was made for about $90 million, not including marketing. It's estimated come in around $30 million this weekend. It's a big gamble for Sony, which has sort of banked a lot of its recent slate on non-franchise comic book movies. The first weekend is not what matters with this movie, it's really with the second and the third. This movie could play very well going well into September.

SMITH: Mike, is this a watershed moment, though, you think for Hollywood? As you pointed out, this is old school. This is how they used to make movie stock --

TAMMERO: This is how they used to do it, right? Yes.

SMITH: Do you think if this bombs Hollywood, say, look, nothing but comic book movies and sequels from now on.

TAMMERO: We'll that's sort of the risk into thinking what -- to date has been this kind of movie really belongs in streaming because that's where we've been watch. That's where I watch.

MCDOWELL: You blaspheme Tarantino does not belong in streaming. He belongs on big screen.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: He is the rarity in Hollywood. He is an artist.

TAMMERO: He really is.

MCDOWELL: He is an old school filmmaker and his success whether -- because again, he went through that very long, dry spell and then he had "Kill Bill," volume one and two, and he came back with "Inglorious Basterds," which I think is his highest grossing film.

BARTIROMO: I love that film.

MCDOWELL: And there's nothing like going to see a Tarantino movie on opening night. People cheer. They cheer at the opening credits and they cheer during the closing.

TAMMERO: Huge Tarantino fan. I saw "Pulp Fiction," (INAUDIBLE) came out and I ran out of the room. That's all I'm saying. I was out of there.

MCDOWELL: I saw "Pulp Fiction."

BARTIROMO: Well, "Pulp Fiction", "Kill Bill" --

TAMMERO: I went out of there, and I was like -- what the heck?

BARTIROMO: -- "Inglorious Basterds," I mean, these are --

TAMMERO: "Django Unchained," yes.

BARTIROMO: The best one, though -- his best film, I highly recommend it: "Jackie Brown." That is his best movie, I think.

BARTIROMO: Is that right? OK. I don't think I've seen that one. How about the trailer for highly-anticipated: "A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood," debuting this week as well. The film star is Tom Hanks, as iconic tv host, Mr. Rogers. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think the best thing we can do is to let people know that each one of them is precious.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: He really looks like him. Michael, your thoughts on that.

TAMMERO: I mean, he has it down. Just onto Oscar right now.

BARTIROMO: Really?

TAMMERO: I mean, this -- over 60 million people viewed this trailer when it debuted in spark over 200,000 social media conversations. I think a lot of people are looking forward to this movie a lot. He's still a beloved character to this day and opens up in Thanksgiving.

BARTIROMO: Cool.

MCDOWELL: If you're too lazy to go see "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood," Pam Grier in "Jackie Brown," you will watch it five times in a row. You'll never leave your living room.

BARTIROMO: Awesome. Good stuff this weekend. And I know your interview with Samuel Jackson from "Spider-man."

TAMMERO: I did. "Spider-man: Far from Home" is about to cross a billion- dollar mark and other Sony movie. Interviewed him. He's 12-time playing Nick Fury. I asked him what it's like if it's still fresh? And then he a had little fun at Daniel Craig expense. Let's take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SAMUEL JACKSON, HOLLYWOOD ACTOR: I'm not James Bond. I'm not looking for another job. I'm OK with being Nick Fury for however long they need me to be him.

JAKE GYLLENHAAL, HOLLYWOOD ACTOR: I can't see -- there's nothing --

JACKSON: -- associated with these characters anymore. I mean, this is the easiest way for me to be John Wayne and I'll figure it out. Yes, John Wayne, sure. Nick Fury.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TAMMERO: He's the best.

BARTIROMO: Love it.

TAMMERO: Great job security.

BARTIROMO: Michael, thank you. Have a great weekend.

TAMMERO: You, too.

BARTIROMO: Michael Tammero. Still ahead, earnings on deck this morning; we are moments away from Twitter's quarterly report. McDonald's out in about an hour. All the numbers and the reaction when we come back. Then, of course, we're gearing up for the GDP report that's out in about an hour- and-a-half. Next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. TGIF! It is Friday, July 26th. Breaking news this morning --

urn:contentItem:5X4F-HT21-JB5M-W062-00000-00Amazon's September 25 event: New high-end Echo speaker, AirPod rival expected2019-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:53ZLexisNexisAmazon's September 25 event: New high-end Echo speaker, AirPod rival expectedAnuj Bhatia

Over the past two years, Amazon has held a fall event at its headquarters in Seattle, Washington, to reveal what's new it has to show in hardware. The idea is to create the hype around its products ahead of entering the crucial holiday season. The company held a similar event last year where it unveiled as many as 15 new products, including a redesigned Echo Dot and an Alexa-enabled microwave oven. The event was held in the Amazon Spheres, the three large glass domes at Amazon's headquarters.

This year, Amazon is holding an event in Seattle on Wednesday, September 25, where it is expected to announce new hardware and services. Amazon has already spent a lot of time showing off new third-party Amazon products at this year's Internationale Funkausstellung - otherwise known as IFA, Wednesday's event is most likely focus on the updated Echo hardware and a new truly wireless earbuds with Alexa built-in.

'High-end Echo speaker expected'

At the event, Amazon VP of device David Limp and team will likely show off a new high-end Echo with a built-in woofer and better sound quality. The tech giant recently announced a new tier for its music subscription service that will offer high quality, lossless audio streams and downloads. It would make sense for Amazon to launch an Echo with more premium sound that can actually compete with the Google Home Max, Sonos One and Apple's HomePod in the sound department

"Amazon is overdue to create a music-grade version of the Echo that can compete with the Sonos One for high-quality music listening solo or in stereo pairs. They're also likely to refresh the large Echo speaker, but not the Echo Dot," said Forrester Research analyst Frank Gillett.

'Echo speaker central to smart home'

For Amazon, the Echo smart speaker is central to the smart home experience. The Echo, which has more than 80,000 skills, support dozens of smart home devices and can be used to shop products on Amazon. According to market research firm Canalys, Amazon's Echo is the most popular smart speaker in the world, with roughly 25 per cent of the market.

The Echo is so popular that Amazon now sells the smart speaker in various models. The lineup includes the standard Echo, the Echo Dot, the touch-screen enabled Echo Show, a weird looking Echo Spot, the Echo Look, and the Echo Plus. And it's no surprise to see why Amazon keeps updating its Echo lineup of speakers each year. Last year, Amazon refreshed the Echo Dot, Echo Show and the Echo Show at its September event. This year, Amazon is expected to update the standard Echo and Echo Spot.

Every Amazon Echo speaker is powered by Alexa, a voice assistant that can listen to you and respond with answers to questions in English, Hindi and yes, Hinglish, a hybrid of Hindi and English. Rather than a Google search, you can ask out the word "Alexa" at the beginning of the question on a compatible device to answer all your queries.

'Amazon faces scrutiny over privacy practices'

But as Alexa-powered Echo speakers surged in popularity, the issue of privacy cast a shadow on the company's policy to protect user data. Like other big tech firms, including Google and Apple, Amazon too has been accused of hiring workers listening and transcribing commands on an "Alexa" device. In the wake of increasing pressure from privacy regulators, Amazon did give users the option to disable human review of their Alexa recording. Previously, Amazon did not inform users that their audio recordings might be listened to by its workers. Amazon's latest move shows that major tech companies have come under pressure from regulators to improve transparency and give users more control over the data.

'Amazon may launch AirPods rival'

Amazon is also expected to release a pair of truly wireless earbuds at the event. The rumoured Alexa-powered wireless earbuds may end up costing $100 and will able to track running distance, calories burned and pace, according to reports. This would be the first time the company will launch Amazon-branded wireless earbuds in the market.

"The virtual assistant is the chance for Amazon to get to the same level of influence as Apple and Google have as smartphone OS makers. If they can get Alexa into wireless headphones, they can get influence at the same level as the smartphone OS maker," Gillett said.

Many believe Amazon's wireless earbuds will be the answer to Apple AirPods, the world's most popular truly wireless earbuds. The $149 AirPods are so popular that you will find them in the coffee shops, airports and in the gym. Amazon needed to be in space to bring Alexa to the ear.

"Amazon's first wireless earbuds will be a quality "affordable" set of wireless earbuds that can bring Alexa directly into consumers' daily interactions on their smartphones, rather than just via smart speakers. This is crucial to expand Alexa's reach in Europe where Google Assistant has been able to land first or follow faster, due to Google's global experience with search translation and localization," he explained.

'No wheeled robot, Kindle readers expected at the event'

The e-commerce giant is also expected to announce new Fire tablets at the September 25 event. Don't expect Amazon to unveil a wheeled robot, a new smartphone, or new Kindle readers at its fall event, Gillett said.

There are talks of Amazon launching a new service at the event. Gillett believes Amazon will add an Alexa tier to Amazon Prime, but the announcement won't happen anytime soon. The new tier will enable premium services, like video storage, family services, or food delivery.

(Disclaimer: The author is in Seattle on the invite of Amazon India.)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5P62-M611-DY2P-42B4-00000-00Amazon's size brings antitrust concerns2017-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:53ZLexisNexisROP ZONEPg. A1Amazon's size brings antitrust concernsÁngel GonzálezSeattle Times business reporter

Amazon.com, America's fifth-largest company by market value, is still growing like an adolescent and planting flags in new markets. That is prompting some policymakers and legal experts to ask: How big is too big?

It's a key issue for an economy being rapidly reshaped by e-commerce, a sector where Amazon and the merchants operating on its platform account for up to a third of all U.S. sales, according to some estimates.

It's also critical for Seattle, a city that has hitched its wagon to the e-commerce titan, and that once saw another local champion, Microsoft, mired in a lengthy antitrust battle. That fight, over Microsoft keeping a rival internet browser off PCs running Windows, almost led to the split-up of the Redmond software giant.

E-commerce is not Amazon's only game. It also dominates cloud computing, and it may soon have a significant brick-and-mortar presence, with its pending acquisition of Whole Foods Market. The unexpected $13.7 billion deal announced in June spurred an outcry among critics of the company and some members of Congress who asked the Federal Trade Commission to take a close look at the deal.

Last month Marc Perrone, president of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, which represents grocery workers, wrote to the FTC that Amazon's proposed takeover of the organic food purveyor "is a competitive threat to our economy that will hurt workers and communities."

Legal experts say it's really hard to build an antitrust case against the Whole Foods deal, which would give Amazon just a small percentage of the U.S. grocery market.

Amazon's budding dominance in other markets, too, is likely to remain unchallenged in the long term, unless the philosophy underlying antitrust regulations changes. In fact, U.S. regulators have sided with Amazon against its rivals' anti-competitive moves - such as when they charged Apple and top New York publishers with conspiring to raise prices for e-books, a market Amazon dominates.

Under the current U.S. antitrust view, how consumers are treated is the prime factor, not the company's dominance in a market. To take antitrust action against Amazon, regulators would have to prove that the company somehow harms shoppers - for example, by conspiring to make the products they buy artificially more expensive. Another way Amazon could run into trouble is by undermining rivals with strategies such as sustained predatory pricing or forcing suppliers to lock out competitors.

But rather than using tactics like that, some experts say, Amazon has built its empire just by giving customers what they want - products at low prices with lots of choices - which is not against the rules, no matter how big it grows.

"Antitrust law doesn't make it illegal to get market power," provided it was done properly, said A. Douglas Melamed, a professor of antitrust law at Stanford University and a former U.S. Department of Justice antitrust official.

Amazon's humongous size is "politically important," but not an antitrust issue. "Not if they got there by being more innovative and more creative than the next guy," he said.

At the same time, the huge role occupied by Amazon - and other big tech firms such as Google and Facebook - is fostering a rethinking among policy wonks about how government can oversee the power of these large tech companies.

"A lot of people are waking up to the fact that Amazon has positioned itself as a central piece of infrastructure for the 21st century economy," said Lina Khan, a fellow at the New America Foundation, a Washington, D.C., think tank. She is also author of "Amazon's Antitrust Paradox," which has attracted widespread attention since it was published in January by the Yale Law Journal.

"We need to rethink how to go about preserving competition," she said in an interview.

Amazon downplays the antitrust issue. During a recent call with reporters, Amazon Chief Financial Officer Brian Olsavsky said that "the businesses we are in are all very large market segments with lots of very serious competition."

Nevertheless, the company last year hired a veteran D.C. antitrust adviser, Seth Bloom.

Amazon's North American retail sales, which include Canada, totaled about $80 billion in 2016. That doesn't include sales by third-party merchants operating on Amazon's site, which some experts estimate to be about the same, or more.

Together, Amazon and its merchants account for about a third of all online sales. But e-commerce is a tiny part - about 8.15 percent - of the huge U.S. retail sector.

Amazon grows fast, however. In the latest quarter, the company's sales grew 25 percent, to $38 billion, and the company is on track to becoming the second-largest U.S. employer among the Fortune 500, after Wal-Mart.

It dominates some markets, such as e-books. In others, it's growing so quickly that it makes incumbents quake. For instance, analysts with Cowen estimate that Amazon might surpass Macy's as the biggest seller of clothes this year.

When a rumor arises that Amazon might dip its toe in a new market, stocks for potential rivals tremble, as happened to Zillow in June amid reports of a potential Amazon service for real-estate agents.

Even more important than its retail power, in the eyes of some policymakers, is Amazon's increasingly central role as a platform widely used by other retailers. Brands now feel compelled to hawk their wares on Amazon's site, the biggest destination for online shoppers.

Many merchants also pay to use Amazon's logistics, having their products stored and shipped by the Seattle giant. Amazon, the largest purveyor of cloud computing, even rents competitors the computing capacity they need to operate their businesses.

Khan, the New America fellow, likens Amazon to the 19th century railroad empires that farmers and manufacturers relied on to get their products to market - and whose power generated public concern that led to the creation of the first federal antitrust laws.

"Today you have to ride Amazon's rails," she said.

Current antitrust laws, which focus on protecting efficiency and consumer prices, are ill-suited to regulate that type of power. They also don't fully take into account how Amazon's bevy of mutually reinforcing businesses can undermine competition, Khan argues.

But that regulatory framework could change. In the past year, the attention the issue has been getting from the media and members of Congress on both sides of the aisle "has been mind-blowing," Khan said.

In a recent Op-Ed in The New York Times , Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., pointed to more strict oversight of corporate giants as one of the main points of the Democratic Party program.

"We are going to fight to allow regulators to break up big companies if they're hurting consumers and to make it harder for companies to merge if it reduces competition," he wrote.

Experts say the Whole Foods deal is likely to sail through, despite the initial controversy.

Melamed, the Stanford professor, said that the grocery chain and Amazon today barely compete. Whole Foods, with annual sales of about $16 billion, represents a tiny sliver of the $600 billion U.S. grocery market. And Amazon's U.S. grocery and pantry sales totaled just $400 million in the first quarter of 2017, according to calculations by One Click Retail, an e-commerce consultancy.

In the longer term, too, Melamed sees a relatively clear runway for Amazon, as long as it behaves.

He acknowledged there is some restlessness among experts regarding the relative passivity of antitrust regulators in recent decades.

"There's an increasing sentiment, even among the antitrust technocrats, that perhaps antitrust law has not been aggressive enough," he said. That laxity has allowed, in the eyes of critics, a series of gigantic deals across the U.S. economy that have increased market concentration.

But Melamed expects any regulatory changes that may occur to be relatively minor - perhaps closer scrutiny of upcoming deals, or looking at a longer-term horizon when projecting whether a merger might result in competitive harm.

A bigger challenge to Amazon might come from Europe.

Last June, the European Commission fined Google some $2.7 billion for allegedly giving its own price-comparison service an illegal advantage by featuring it prominently in search results.

Melamed said European regulators don't like the creation of monopolies, even if they result from disruptive practices that would be considered acceptable in the U.S. "If you wind up driving your only competitor out of business, it's going to land you in trouble in Europe."

It's hard to know how this could impact Amazon. But the company has already had run-ins with European antitrust regulators. In 2015 the European Commission began investigating Amazon's e-book distribution agreements with publishers, which required the publishers to share with Amazon information about the terms they struck with Amazon's competitors, and to give it the same or better terms.

Amazon agreed not to enforce those clauses and to drop them from future contracts, a commitment the Commission made legally binding in May.

Back in the U.S., even though building a case against Amazon might be hard, it doesn't mean rivals or critics won't try.

The disruptive effect of Amazon's expansion on competitors could force some politically connected firms to ask regulators for help, said David Teece, director of the Tusher Center for the Management of Intellectual Capital at the Haas School of Business at UC Berkeley. "The greater the disruption, the more likelihood the antitrust agencies are going to stick their nose in it," he said.

Communication will be key for the titan.

"Amazon's not there yet. But when it gets to be dominant, it has to be careful, make sure all its conduct is pro-competitive and the public understands it," he added.

"You can't ignore Washington, D.C. Bill Gates learned that."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WP1-XJH1-DYDW-713C-00000-00Amazon's Spending on One-Day Delivery Dents Profit, Trims Forecast2019-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:53ZLexisNexisAmazon's Spending on One-Day Delivery Dents Profit, Trims ForecastNew Delhi, 2019-07-29 15:52:53

July 29 -- Amazon.com's results were marred by a surge in costs tied to its one-day delivery push, worrying investors who had grown accustomed to almost two straight years of fattening profits.
 
 
Moving millions of products closer to customers to enable one-day delivery proved more costly and complicated than expected, driving up expenses and reducing efficiency in the second quarter, Chief Financial Officer Brian Olsavsky said July 25 on a conference call. The investment will put a strain on earnings for the rest of the year but already has spurred consumers to buy more on Amazon's website and helped revenue growth rebound, he said.


"It does create a shock to the system now," Olsavsky said of the speedier delivery effort. "We'll work through that over the next several quarters and when the dust settles, we'll return to increased efficiency."
The Seattle-based company announced in April that it would spend $800 million to quicken delivery times for its best customers, a response to competition from rivals such as Walmart Inc.Amazon's spending in the past three months ended a six-quarter streak of increased profits from its North American e-commerce business that had fueled investor enthusiasm.
The company reported second-quarter profit was $5.22 per share, missing analysts' average estimate of $5.56 a share. Revenue increased 20% to $63.4 billion, Amazon said in a statement. Analysts, on average, estimated $62.5 billion, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The company also said operating income in the current quarter will be $2.1 billion to $3.1 billion, well shy of analyst estimates of $4.34 billion.
The third quarter is the period when Amazon typically invests in its facilities for the busy holiday shopping season at the end of the year, so big spending on the one-day shipping initiative spooked investors, said RJ Hottovy, an analyst at Morningstar Inc.
"The company's been pretty upfront about investing in one-day shipping," he said. "This is their heaviest investment period of the year, so it's when we're most likely to see a pullback."
Amazon's spending growth in the second quarter accelerated across the board, including for marketing to promote the annual Prime Day sale and on technology and content, which includes money for engineers and video programming. Operating expenses increased 21% to $60.3 billion in the period ended June 30, a faster pace than revenue. Shipping costs increased 36% to $8.13 billion.
While e-commerce remains Amazon's biggest source of sales, other businesses such as cloud computing, logistics for online merchants and advertising are growing faster and now generate almost half of the company's quarterly revenue. In addition to greater competition, Amazon faces increasing scrutiny from government antitrust regulators and lawmakers who argue Amazon acts like a monopoly to dominate online shopping. The U.S. Department of Justice announced July 23 it was opening a broad antitrust review into whether big technology companies are using their power to blunt competition.
"Regulator risk is the No. 1 risk for the big tech companies, including Amazon," said Tom Forte, an analyst at DA Davidson & Co.
Amazon shares declined about 1.5% in extended trading after closing at $1,973.82 in New York. The stock has gained 31% this year, pushing the company's market value near the $1 trillion mark it surpassed briefly last September.
Amazon Web Services sales increased 37% to $8.38 billion in the second quarter, missing analyst estimates of $8.5 billion. Cloud computing is one of Amazon's most profitable businesses, fueling investments in other parts of the company.
Despite the disappointing profit outlook, Amazon has a track record of making long-term investments that ultimately pay off, said Ron Josey, an analyst at JMP Securities.
"They've got some growing pains on one-day, but they're managing that pretty well," he said. "That can only be a good thing longer term, and, frankly, that's how I think the market will be looking at it."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VFG-GTN1-JBCN-4165-00000-00Amazon's stormy week will blow over, but debris may stay2019-02-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:53ZLexisNexisC: LIVINGPg. C06Amazon's stormy week will blow over, but debris may stay

SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - It's been a complicated few weeks for Amazon, what with its abrupt pullout from a massive New York City development, extortion claims related to intimate photos taken by its founder Jeff Bezos and increasing antitrust scrutiny in Europe . For now, these events seem unlikely to pose much threat to Amazon's brand or business. But they're indicative of the mounting challenges the e-commerce giant faces as it grows ever larger and more dominant.

Amazon's turn in the spotlight is a natural consequence of its prominence in retail, entertainment and internet infrastructure, Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives said. "As you get bigger and more successful, you have more of a target on your back," he said.

Few analysts believe Thursday's reversal in New York or the previous week's dust-up with the publisher of the National Enquirer will have much impact on consumer enthusiasm for Amazon's broad product selection and services or its fast shipping.

Bezos has accused the Enquirer of "extortion and blackmail " for threatening to disclose revealing personal photos unless he ended his private investigation into how the tabloid obtained his private exchanges with his mistress.

Investors don't appear particularly concerned that these issues will distract the hard-driving Bezos, who is also in the midst of a divorce - generally considered one of life's most stressful events. Even if Bezos were to find his attention otherwise occupied, Evercore ISI analyst Anthony DiClemente notes that the Amazon chief has a trusted senior leadership team in place. "That gives investors comfort," he said.

Amazon shares have more than made up a brief drop after Bezos made his public case against the Enquirer last week.

Public anger at tech companies has been growing for some time, but much of it has been focused on Facebook and other tech companies that collect vast amounts of personal user information for targeting online ads and other purposes.

Facebook's privacy issues have been particularly acute since they involve the company's core business, said Paul Argenti, a Dartmouth College professor of corporate communication. Amazon isn't immune to the tech backlash. But Argenti said the company's popularity with consumers won't likely be affected by recent headlines.

"I'm not going to stop ordering my movies and packages from them, and I think that's the way most people will look at it," he said.

Longer-term issues, however, could present a more serious threat. Amazon's New York investment would have put 25,000 jobs in the Long Island City neighborhood of Queens, at a cost of nearly $3 billion in tax breaks. Local activists called that a corporate giveaway, one made even less palatable by Amazon's anti-union stance.

That grass-roots rebellion suggests that people are growing more skeptical of big tech companies, especially when government is cutting them special deals, said Blair Levin, a policy adviser to New Street Research and a former chief of staff to a Federal Communications Commission chairman.

"Time and time again, the public has seen promises made and reality is different," he said. "So they're going to be skeptical of Amazon. And it's across the board, not just Amazon."

Several European nations are also investigating Amazon's alleged anti-competitive activity. On Thursday, Austria's antitrust agency said it is reviewing complaints that the company is favoring its own products and discriminating against other sellers on its e-commerce site. German antitrust authorities and the European Commission are investigating Amazon for similar claims.

In the U.S., politicians are also speaking out against Amazon's practices, said Barry Lynn, executive director of Open Markets, an institution that studies corporate monopolies in the U.S.

Lynn argues that Amazon is a monopoly that should be more heavily regulated by the government. He pointed to comments Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat who is running for president, made last year about Amazon's "anti-competitive" practices.

"The word is out, the discussion is ongoing," Lynn said.

"It's not going to go away, it's only going to get louder."

Amazon, and its founder Jeff Bezos, will continue to face more challenges as it grows larger.AP file photo

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VF3-5T81-JDK3-916M-00000-00Amazon's stormy week will blow over, but debris will stay2019-02-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:53ZLexisNexisPMN BUSINESSAmazon's stormy week will blow over, but debris will stay

SAN FRANCISCO - It's been a complicated few weeks for Amazon, what with its abrupt pullout from a massive New York City development, extortion claims related to intimate photos taken by its founder Jeff Bezos and increasing antitrust scrutiny in Europe .

For now, these events seem unlikely to pose much threat to Amazon's brand or business. But they're indicative of the mounting challenges the e-commerce giant faces as it grows ever larger and more dominant.

Amazon's turn in the spotlight is a natural consequence of its prominence in retail, entertainment and internet infrastructure, Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives said. "As you get bigger and more successful, you have more of a target on your back," he said.

Amazon did not return a request for comment Thursday.

Few analysts believe Thursday's reversal in New York or the previous week's dust-up with the publisher of the National Enquirer will have much impact on consumer enthusiasm for Amazon's broad product selection and services or its fast shipping. Bezos has accused the Enquirer of "extortion and blackmail " for threatening to disclose revealing personal photos unless he ended his private investigation into how the tabloid obtained his private exchanges with his mistress.

Investors don't appear particularly concerned that these issues will distract the hard-driving Bezos, who is also in the midst of a divorce - generally considered one of life's most stressful events. Even if Bezos were to find his attention otherwise occupied, Evercore ISI analyst Anthony DiClemente notes that the Amazon chief has a trusted senior leadership team in place. "That gives investors comfort," he said.

Amazon shares have more than made up a brief drop after Bezos made his public case against the Enquirer last week.

Public anger at tech companies has been growing for some time, but much of it has been focused on Facebook and other tech companies that collect vast amounts of personal user information for targeting online ads and other purposes.

Facebook's privacy issues have been particularly acute since they involve the company's core business, said Paul Argenti, a Dartmouth College professor of corporate communication. Amazon isn't immune to the tech backlash. But Argenti said the company's popularity with consumers won't likely be affected by recent headlines.

"I'm not going to stop ordering my movies and packages from them, and I think that's the way most people will look at it," he said.

Longer-term issues, however, could present a more serious threat. Amazon's New York investment would have put 25,000 jobs in the Long Island City neighbourhood of Queens, at a cost of nearly $3 billion in tax breaks. Local activists called that a corporate giveaway, one made even less palatable by Amazon's anti-union stance.

That grass-roots rebellion suggests that people are growing more skeptical of big tech companies, especially when government is cutting them special deals, said Blair Levin, a policy adviser to New Street Research and a former chief of staff to a Federal Communications Commission chairman.

"Time and time again, the public has seen promises made and reality is different," he said. "So they're going to be skeptical of Amazon. And it's across the board, not just Amazon."

Several European nations are also investigating Amazon's alleged anti-competitive activity. On Thursday, Austria's antitrust agency said it is reviewing complaints that the company is favouring its own products and discriminating against other sellers on its e-commerce site. German antitrust authorities and the European Commission are investigating Amazon for similar claims.

In the U.S., politicians are also speaking out against Amazon's practices, said Barry Lynn, executive director of Open Markets, an institution that studies corporate monopolies in the U.S.

Lynn argues that Amazon is a monopoly that should be more heavily regulated by the government. He pointed to comments Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat who is running for president, made last year about Amazon's "anti-competitive" practices.

"The word is out, the discussion is ongoing," Lynn said. "It's not going to go away, it's only going to get louder."

But for shoppers, everything is business as usual, and the bad news will quickly blow over, Dartmouth's Argenti said.

"We won't be talking about this a year from now, maybe not even a month from now," he said.

--

Anderson reported from New York. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2019 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.
